traders on social media. An investor does not own GameStop, a speculator owns 
GameStop. Let's not confuse speculators with investors. In late January 2021, retail investors turned Wall Street
upside down. They poured into GameStop, now the most notorious meme
stock. Meme stocks are stocks that have gone viral. People buy the stock not because of the company's
underlying fundamentals, but because of its popularity online in forums such as Reddit's WallStreetBets. The term has now entered the public lexicon. GameStop wasn't the first meme stock and it won't be the
last. And it also isn't the first time a meme has had a hand in
real life affairs. Here's a look at how memes captivated the general public
and financial markets. Memes have been a part of internet culture for a long time,
but they predate the World Wide Web by more than a decade. Most people refer to cultural biologist
Richard Dawkins as the creator of memes. He coined the word in his 1976 book, 'The Selfish
Gene'. Corollary to the gene, he named the meme. He uses things like fashion, catchphrases, tunes he says. Little bits of culture get passed around in the process of
that propagation, ideas get transformed, they build on each other. They get bigger and bigger and bigger as more and more
people get in on whatever bit of culture is being passed around. When the Internet was made available to everyone in 1993,
the meme transitioned from real life conversations to quick images that anyone scrolling by with
little context could understand. We've seen a really rapid development in not just a variety
of, say, subgenres of memes, but also how they're deployed, how
they're activated. Be it for fun or what I'm most interested in is how they're
used in political communication and strategic messaging. I view them really as an extension of ideology. Memes not only set these borders between who we are and who
we aren't, they also allow you to diffuse ideas into the group
pretty quickly. And we see this happen in a lot of different contexts. WallStreetBets is one. We see this happen with different
fan groups, right, fans of K-Pop. More problematically, this is a tool used by white
supremacists and white nationalists to play with internet culture and get ideas seeded out to
different Facebook groups. So you have a lot of examples of groups with intentional
strategic communication aims, using funny little clips on the internet to persuade and to
mobilize the people who are paying attention to them. WallStreetBets is a subreddit with more than nine million
members, the community description reads 'like 4chan found a Bloomberg Terminal'. Posts and memes on the subreddit have tongue-in-cheek humor
that frame Wall Street as the enemy. There is a lot of insider lingo. They call themselves 'apes', right, which is kind of this
pejorative label that they're not fancy, that they aren't affluent, that they're not in hedge
funds, they're just everyday people. But this mob of everyday people can have
vast power and vast influence. Memes were a big part of defining who we are and
inspiring that who we are into collective action. With retail investors posting their success on these online
forums, it makes it tempting for readers to want to get in on the quick cash that led to the momentum
that pushed GameStop shares higher in late January 2021. It's extremely compelling. And you're sitting there and you're thinking, 'I can do
this. If that guy can do it, so can I. I have to always say this. It's easy until something comes along in the market and

jump from the internet to dinner tables across America, leading many outside of the community to google

an institution. There are examples over and over collectives of people
coming together and amplifying an idea to the point where mainstream media
outlets, institutional forces have to pay more attention can be
stuff like the Occupy Wall Street protests of 2011, which started as

brutality. And then you've got the problematic ends of the spectrum

over and over again of people getting together and deciding to do something and that having some massive
ramifications. It's hard to define what a meme stock is. Some describe meme stocks as overvalued companies that are
hyped up by online investing communities like WallStreet Bets. Other favorites are stocks heavily shorted by Wall
Street. Investors short a stock when they think it's going to
decline. Hedge fund Melvin Capital and Andrew Left's short seller 
firm Citron Capital bet against brick-and-mortar video game retailer GameStop because they believed the company

but are now past their prime. Meme stocks GameStop, BlackBerry and AMC share these

stopping the momentum of retail investors piling into the stock to push it higher, despite what it may lack in

You've likely heard news reporters say things
like, The Dow is up 100 points, or The S&P is down five points. But what does that mean? The Dow, S&P 500, and Nasdaq are examples
of stock market indices. A stock market index measures the performance
of a collection of stocks. By measuring these stocks collectively, indices
track how the overall market is performing better than only looking at the performance
of a single stock. Think of it this way: if you focus too closely
on just one thing, you might not have a good understanding of the larger picture. This is why an index's performance provides
more complete information than the performance of individual stocks--indices provide a wider
view of the stock market as a whole. The first index was the Dow Jones Industrial
Average, published in 1896. Financial reporter Charles Dow added up the
closing prices of 12 of the largest stocks at the time and divided the total by 12 to
get the average. Today, the Dow consists of 30 of the largest
and most successful companies in the U.S. These companies are handpicked by experts
to represent a wide variety of industries. Some of these companies affect the average
more than others, though, because many indices are weighted. Think of the idea of weighting like grades:
a final exam is going to make up a larger portion of your grade than a daily homework
assignment. In the Dow, companies with higher prices are
given more weight. In 2018, Boeing, the highest priced stock
in the index, made up about 9% of the index whereas Pfizer, the least expensive stock,
was only 1% of the index. So a change in Boeing's price would have
had a greater impact on the Dow than if Pfizer's price changed. While the Dow is the oldest and most well-known
index, some believe that its measurement is less representative of the overall market
than the S&P 500 even though they often perform similarly to each other. The S&P 500 measures the performance of 500
of the largest publicly traded companies in the U.S. Due to its broader exposure, some
believe that the S&P 500 is the best measurement of the U.S. stock market. The S&P 500 is weighted by market cap. Market cap is the number of a company's
outstanding shares multiplied by the price per share. Because of this, the companies with the largest
total market value have the greatest impact on the average of the S&P 500. The Nasdaq Composite, also referred to as
the Nasdaq, includes 3,000 or so companies that are traded on the Nasdaq exchange. The Nasdaq includes more smaller companies
than the other indices, but also includes many of the largest tech companies, like Apple,
Amazon, Microsoft, and Alphabet. Because nearly half of the companies are tech
companies, the Nasdaq is widely considered a better gauge for the Technology industry. Some of these companies may also be included
on the Dow, the S&P 500, or both. Each index helps measure how the overall market
is doing through the performance of the securities it tracks. Though the market may vary day to day, or
even year to year, the historical performances of indices show that over time, the stock
market tends to rise.

Since mid February the US Nasdaq has taken a bit 
of a nose-dive. This has shaken the confidence   amongst several retail investors. But what does 
this mean and is there really reason to worry? Since mid February the US Nasdaq has gone down, 
not necessarily by too much, but rather quite   steeply. We’ve especially seen certain individual 
stocks go down by quite a lot. Tesla -40%,   Amazon -16%, Apple -19%, Nio -50%, and so on. This 
has led to some concern amongst retail investors. But how bad is this really? What can we 
expect from this? And is this the real crash   in the making? This is exactly what 
we’ll discuss in this episode. And   as the US Nasdaq is much of a leading 
index it’ll be our target of focus. But first and as always, nothing in 
this episode is financial advice.   These are my own opinions and conclusions ONLY 
as the markets all come down to probabilities.   In this sense, just because we may 
successfully identify the most likely   outcomes, the market can still end up 
doing the unlikely and the unexpected. And if this episode helps you better understand 
the situation at hand, then please return the   favour by hitting the like and subscribe 
buttons. Let’s now dig into the technicals … So, is this it then? Well, I’m 
gonna give you one answer now   and another at the end. The first answer 
is short and you’re not gonna like it.   The answer is: No one knows. No one knows 
where the peak is until afterwards. Sure,   people might get lucky and sell at the 
very peak, but there’s no way of knowing   when the peak is in. For technical analysis 
is gaming theory and probabilities at work. However, the thing that sets good analysts apart 
from the unknowing herd is that they can identify   such reversals much earlier. And for that 
reason they can enjoy a massive advantage   compared to that of the “dumb money” as they can 
release their long positions or short the market.   For there are several clues that will 
or may materialise to any attentive   trader or technician who has done their homework 
properly. And out of all those clues, the RSI is   the most reliable one whenever it 
decides to bless us with signals. With that said, we will now look at some key   technicals that will reveal whether 
there’s reason to worry or not. And why! A big problem many technicians have, especially 
novice ones, is that they simply fail to zoom out.   For even if you’re trading the 1-hour or 4-hour 
chart, you still need to know what the prevalent   trend is. As in the primary and secular trends. 
If you don’t, then any drops on the lower time   frames may come across as if Armageddon 
and the Kraken monster had a baby together. In this sense, if we look at the 
US Nasdaq on the weekly chart I   quite frankly don’t get what the fuzz 
and panic is all about. For what’s so   worrying about this? It’s a perfectly healthy 
trend. Strong trends correct before proceeding   higher, just like crashes have their most 
temporary rays of optimism before diving   deeper. For when we break things down, what’s 
practically happened here is that the price has   re-tested its previous all-time high 
zone from above as support. That’s it.   And to add to the current 
bullishness we can see how   the price rapidly found support 
and bounced off at this zone. Don’t get me wrong. I can understand why people 
may find this move unpleasant, especially due to   the steepness thereof, for so too would I a few 
years back. But that’s why you proceed to fill   your head with valuable market behaviour knowledge 
and an essential technical understanding. For once   you do, you understand what’s happening. Then, and 
only then, can you sit back amidst the false chaos   and take a sip of your soda pop while watching 
the noobs run around with fire in their hair.   And once you understand the market and its 
behaviours it doesn’t matter whether it goes   up or down: you’ll be getting the best of 
it either way. And this is why I recommend   you to follow this channel, so that you 
too can learn how to stay in control. Let’s now filter all the chart noise and 
identify and isolate the actual signals. If we stay on the weekly Nasdaq chart we 
can make a rather significant observation.   Throughout this 12 year long bull run only one 
correction … one single correction … has taken   out a lower low that wasn’t just a new spike 
low. And that was during the Christmas of 2018.   Even the Corona bottom closed where 
the previous local bottom spiked out,   which technically qualifies for a horizontal 
support and not a lower low. And prior to that,   throughout this vast trend, we can detect 
innumerous accounts of when the price has   re-tested the previous tops as support from 
above. As just mentioned, this is not a cause   for panic – it’s a sign of health! This is exactly 
the stuff we want to see before moving higher. For   this right here is the market’s way of exhaling 
and catching its breath. What would be worrying,   on the other hand, would be if the price were 
to just to go up, up and up. That would be like   running a Marathon at full sprint capacity. You 
wouldn’t get far until your heart gives up on you.   In this sense, these moves here since the Corona 
bottom last year are utterly normal corrections. I would go as far as to say that the US Nasdaq 
can go as low as the previous local bottoms at   around 10 700 and still be perfectly healthy. 
Sure, that would scare the living hell out of   most market participants, retailers in 
particular, but that’s what the market   does! It’s in its very programming. That’s in fact 
where you should look at scaling in longs, albeit   with a tight stop-loss. There are three technical 
reasons for this. Please allow me to explain. First of all, and as we can see, any time 
throughout this 12 year-long bull run any   break below the EMA ribbons has so far amounted to 
wonderful buy opportunities where the market has   rubber-banded itself back up again. Now, 
don’t get me wrong, for at some point the   US Nasdaq will go below these ribbons and not 
recover for many years to come. But this is   where technical analysis is all about assessing 
probabilities and laying a big jigsaw puzzle.   For what has every EMA ribbon break had 
in common historically? That is apart   from one! What they have in common is that 
they haven’t taken out their previous local   bottoms. In this sense, this 2018 Christmas 
plunge was certainly a technical cause for worry.   And I would go as far as to say that it wasn’t 
back to bullish again until at this point here. Secondly, the weekly EMA50 lingers 
like a river at around 11 500 bucks.   This in itself amounts to a strong technical 
support when dealing with secular trends.   With that said, it doesn’t mean it necessarily 
needs to bounce exactly on the line. If we look at   its historical behaviour it has dived beneath this 
on multiple occasions throughout this bull trend   and each and every time it has found its way 
back up again. What this means is that there   is technical leeway. For even though there’s a 
good chance it may bounce on that line precisely,   it can move under for short periods of 
time without necessarily having breeched it   technically. Of course, any retest from 
below is always a critical moment. However,   so far it has not failed to 
do so once in twelve years. But my point here is that a test 
or temporary breach of the EMA50   won’t mean much as long as the 
safety net at 10 700 holds up. And thirdly, we have a big, nice green Ichimoku 
cloud that supports this very level. And if we   examine this entire trend the price has, just as 
with the EMA50, never managed to stay below it for   any significant time at all – all of which rather 
have amounted to strong buying opportunities.   Instead, whenever we’ve interacted with the 
green kumos, the price has nicely respected it. By that token, the 10 700 area is a strong yet 
very critical one. Any break below it would not   only plunge us below the ribbons, weekly EMA50 
and green ichimoku. They would also take out a   new local low. This could be a strong indication 
of a secular trend reversal. However, in any such   event I doubt the US Nasdaq would just throw 
itself straight down into the abyss. Instead,   I’d rather be looking at a retest at the 11 900 to 
12 300 area. And this I’d expect for two reasons.   First of all it would be a nice bounce for the 
market to lull unassuming sheep into a sense of   false security. A “the worst is over now” type of 
denial. For that’s typically how the market acts   before proceeding with the real plummet. Secondly, 
this area would constitute a strong resistance   zone for all the reasons just outlined. That area 
would then constitute a shorting area of interest. But let’s get back to the core analysis, for this 
here is getting a bit ahead of ourselves. The   reason why I bring this up at all is to let you 
into my technical reasoning as the same principles   will apply at any point from here on. For let’s 
look at it this way. If we proceed to make higher   highs, which statistically and technically 
speaking is the most likely scenario, then   we will establish new critical areas. Hence if we, 
by the same logic, were to move to 15 000 bucks,   then this area right here at 12 300 would be the 
new critical area of interest, at which any break   below it would be an indication of a possible 
secular trend reversal. Are you following? Of course, having said this, we’d ideally be given 
RSI shorting signals way in advance and way closer   to the very peak. If this were to play out then 
it would come across as nothing short of magical   to anyone who’s oblivious to these techniques. 
In any such case, they’ll be our little secret. Some technicians may raise the issue about 
the three-point RSI divergence on the weekly   that stretches back to pre-corona. And the 
three-point divergence on the monthly that   has now been broken. But as anyone knows who’s 
watched the RSI trilogy, an RSI divergence in   itself doesn’t really mean anything. They 
happen all the time! No, a divergence is   only interesting and relevant in relation to its 
technical context. From December 2013 until August   2015 we had a year and a half long RSI divergence, 
yet the price proceeded higher without much ado. On a final note, so far this trend looks perfectly 
healthy from a technical point of view. But don’t   be fooled, for fundamentally it’s all a house 
of cards that’s waiting to come crashing down. How then about that second answer that I promised 
you? The one about whether this is “it”? Well,   in that sense my answer is: No, I don’t think 
this is it. And there are two reasons for this,   one psychological and one technical. The short psychological reason is 
that markets don’t end when people   expect it to. It’s much too sadistic and conniving 
for that. Instead, it will bide its time like a   crocodile in the Nile who strikes when the prey 
least expects it. And so too will the market. The technical reason is that it’s pretty much an 
isolated event on the US Nasdaq. For look at the   S&P500, you can barely tell from the

Welcome to the Investors Trading Academy talking
glossary of financial terms and events. Our word of the day is “NASDAQ”
The NASDAQ is a global electronic marketplace for buying and selling securities, as well
as the benchmark index for U.S. technology stocks. NASDAQ was created by the National Association
of Securities Dealers to enable investors to trade securities on a computerized, speedy
and transparent system, and commenced operations on February 8, 1971. The NASDAQ computerized trading system was
initially devised as an alternative to the inefficient “specialist” system, which
had been the prevalent model for almost a century. The rapid evolution of technology has made
the NASDAQ’s electronic trading model the standard for markets worldwide. As a leader in trading technology from the
outset, it was only fitting that the world’s technology giants chose to list on the NASDAQ
in their early days. As the technology sector grew in prominence
in the 1980s and 1990s, the NASDAQ became the most widely followed proxy for this sector.

I am attorney Laura Anthony founding partner
of Legal & Compliance, a full service corporate, securities, and business transactions law
firm. Today is the final LawCast in a series discussing
NASDAQ listing requirements. There are many benefits to trading on an exchange
such as NASDAQ. The biggest benefit to an exchange is the
ability to attract analyst coverage and institutional investors, and the corresponding increase
in liquidity that comes with both. Stocks that trade on NASDAQ tend to have a
lower bid/offer spread than over the counter securities, again, encouraging trading volume
and liquidity. Importantly, exchange traded securities are
exempt from the penny stock definition, allowing for more market maker and broker-dealer participation. A broker-dealer cannot recommend a penny stock
transaction to its retail customers, and therefore, no analysts, financial advisors, or institutional
investors make recommendations for purchases of penny stocks. And, in general, no institutional investors
invest in penny stocks. As an aside, this is one of the reasons that
OTC Markets created the OTCQX Market tier, which does not list penny stocks. It is also the reason that the small- and
micro-cap industry is pushing for a supported venture exchange. A designated venture market would be one for
small-cap companies, which would allow for higher brokerage and trading commissions,
be exempt from the prohibitive penny stock rules, and which securities would be considered
covered securities under federal securities laws and thus exempt from separate blue sky
compliance. I think that the OTC Markets has the foundation
to set the OTCQX as a recognized venture exchange platform and would love to see it gain regulatory
support in that regard, including blue sky pre-emption. In today’s world it is increasingly difficult
to deposit and/or trade in non-exchange traded securities. Despite the congressional efforts and SEC
rulemaking in support of small and micro-cap capital formation — for example, the JOBS
Act, including the emerging growth company regulations and IPO on-ramp. New Regulation A+ and Title III Crowdfunding
and the new FAST Act – through enforcement and investigative proceedings, both the SEC
and FINRA continue to apply pressure on broker-dealers, clearing firms and transfer agents, resulting
in a reduction in a secondary trading and free flow of low priced securities. Although these issues need to be addressed
on a broader basis, securities listed on NASDAQ and other national exchanges do not face many
of these issues. Also as mentioned, exchange traded securities
are considered covered securities for purposes of blue sky compliance. That is, transactions with exchange traded
securities are exempted from separate state blue sky law registration and exemption requirements. I am securities attorney Laura Anthony, founding
partner of Legal & Compliance, and producer of LawCast. Should you have any questions about today’s
topic, please visit SecuritiesLawBlog.com and LawCast.com, or contact me directly. Inquiries of a technical nature are always
encouraged.

hello guys so today we are going to talk about a really important topic which will also be interesting so what do you think it is no idea yes we are going to talk about something which is in more conversations recently and that is the gamestop short squeeze so what is this so called short squeeze hang out i'll be discussing what your squeeze is in many different points throughout the video but before we get into it do me a favor and smash that like button subscribe to the channel and hit the bell button for notifications whenever a new video is published and let's get started so basically the first question that comes to your mind is what this short squeeze is and what is gamestop gamestop corporation is an american video game consumer electronics and gaming merchandise retailer the company's headquarters are in grapevine texas united states gamestop is the largest video game retailer having over 5 000 retail stores operating under it in the united states canada australia new zealand and europe gamestop eb games thinkgeek and micromania zing are brands that primarily operate the retail stores under the company now let's talk about what a short squeeze is a short squeeze occurs when a stock or other asset jumps sharply higher forcing traders who had bet that its price would fall to buy it in order to forestall even greater losses so this is what happened in the gamestop short squeeze the two main billionaire hedge funds in the story are melvin capital and citron research in the gamestop short squeeze melvin citron and the rest of the others shorted gamestop stocks let's get to a quick review about melvin and citron melvin capital management lp is an american investment management firm based in new york city melvin capital invests primarily in tech and consumer stocks and as of january 2021 it is reported to have 8 billion us dollars under management however they had to suffer a lot after undergoing a loss of 53 percent during the gamestop short squeeze let's switch gears to citron research cichon research is an online investment newsletter that provides short focused stock market commentary it has published reports covering a range of companies based in the united states and china andrew left is the founder and executive editor of citron research however it is one of the main companies that had to suffer due to the short squeeze of gamestop this happened when melvin and citron immediately sold their shares of gamestop which they had borrowed previously putting up a margin requirement and then waited for gamestop stock prices to drop the crew of the wall street bets said once if we all start buying tons of gamestop stock we'll drive the price way up the billionaires will pay tons of margin calls and then they will have to repurchase the stocks probably from us at huge prices we'll make money and the billionaires will lose money and that's exactly what happened so if we are to break it down further more gamestop company after hitting an all-time low of 2.80 per share in april 2020 again gamestop closed at 65 and shot up to 51 that same day it even hit a high of 76 during the day getting the stock altered several times due to it moving so quickly so why do you think all this happened well gamestop had over 138 percent of its float shares sold short making it the most shorted stock in the united states stock market let's break that down further float shares are the number of shares available for trading of a particular stock so over 100 of these shares are sold short so what does that mean it basically means wall street hates this particular stock and expects its value to fall the way that it works is that they would borrow the stock sell it and then buy it back after the stock value has fallen the price difference between what they sell it for and what they buy it back for is their profit so essentially if they sell gamestop at twenty dollars and then the stock price falls to five dollars they just profit at fifteen dollars so if someone thinks the company is overvalued they can make money when that stock price falls in value now the thing with short selling is that there is theoretically infinite risk since there is no ceiling on how high a stock price can go so let's say that gamestop stock went up to 200 and the short seller who sold the stock for 20 now has to buy it back at that price so simply they just lost 180 per share and that is why investing in stocks can be risky and what if gamestop went to 1 000 then they will lose 980 dollars per share so in theory there are infinite losses with short selling so the other thing you may be questioning is how can they short more shares than there are shares available well let's scale things down and for example let's say gamestop issued 300 shares of their stock a fund wants to short the stocks so they borrow 200 shares and then they sell them to a certain company and this company does stock lending and someone else comes along and they also want a short game stop so the company lends them the 200 shares and they go out and sell them this means that there are 400 shares now sold short out of only 300 shares available now i guess that was a bit complicated but i brought it up just to show you guys how it works it can be an endless cycle of borrowing and selling but the thing is short sellers have to pay interest when they borrow these shares so it costs them a lot of money to hold this position so that means if a stock goes up when they are expected to go down these short sellers have to hold that position while still paying interest remember if the price goes up shorts are losing money they had to borrow those shares at interest and so the more the price goes up the more those shorts are getting squeezed out of their position and having to buy back at higher prices causing them to lose the money and that's what basically a short squeeze is so the next question is when will a short squeeze occur actually it can't be predicted because obviously no one really knows how high the price will go it can occur several times a year sooner or later now moving on to the next thing some may wonder whether shorting is actually a legal thing to do some may see this as a kind of manipulation so is the gamestop short squeeze legal so if you can see the stock market as a game it also has some
